Ich przywódcą jest Brughor Axe-Biter - dziki brutal, który bardziej niż zwiadem interesuje się mordowaniem i plądrowaniem.

entries.name: Orc Camp
entries: Wyvern Tor to sporej wielkości wzgórze, na którego zboczach i stokach rozciągają się kilometry nierównego terenu. Poszukiwanie ukrytego obozu orków wymaga czasu. Grupa może próbować wykonać jeden test Mądrości DC 15 ({@skill Perception}) lub Mądrości DC 10 ({@skill Survival}) na godzinę, aby znaleźć obóz, wykonywany przez postać prowadzącą.
Gdy bohaterowie znajdą obóz, przeczytaj poniższe fragmenty:

W powietrzu unosi się słaby zapach dymu, gdy wchodzisz na nierówny grzbiet na niższych zboczach wzgórza. Pięćdziesiąt metrów dalej, na dnie wąwozu, otwiera się otwór jaskini. Dwadzieścia metrów za jaskinią przy głazie siedzi samotny ork i pełni wartę.

Jeśli bohaterom uda się po cichu i sprawnie zlikwidować samotnika {@creature orc}, mają szansę zaskoczyć orków w jaskini. Jeśli wartownik zauważy, że bohaterowie się skradają, lub jeśli nie zostanie uciszony podczas rundy zaskoczenia, ork wycofuje się z powrotem do jaskini, aby ostrzec pozostałych.

Do maruderów w jaskini należą Brughor Topornik ({@creature orc} z 30 punktami trafień), sześciu zwykłych {@creature orc||orcs} i plugawy {@creature ogre} Gog. Gog walczy, dopóki nie zostanie zabity, podczas gdy orkowie walczą, dopóki Brughor nie zostanie zabity, a wtedy pozostali orkowie uciekają.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: W drodze do Wyvern Tor banda Brughora splądrowała kilka zagród położonych dalej na północ. W odblokowanej skrzyni ze skarbami w jaskini znajduje się 750 cp, 180 sp, 62 ep, 30 gp i trzy fiolki z perfumami (każda po 10 gp).

entries.name: Awarding Experience Points
entries: Pokonanie potworów w Wyvern Tor kończy misję zleconą przez burmistrza miasta Harbina Westera w Phandalin, a także spełnia obietnicę daną Hamunowi Kostowi w Starej Sowiej Studni. Podziel 1250 XP po równo między bohaterów, jeśli partia rozprawi się z orkami i ogrem.

entries.name: Cragmaw Castle
entries: Plemię Cragmaw składa się z grasujących band i rywalizujących ze sobą goblinich gospodarstw, rozrzuconych po całym obszarze Szlaku Triboar i Lasu Nigdy Więcej. Jednak jeden wódz jest niechętnie uznawany przez wszystkich za najwyższego: król Grol z zamku Cragmaw.

Zamek Cragmaw nie jest konstrukcją goblinów, ani też nie jest to jego pierwotna nazwa. Wzniesiona przez utalentowanego czarodzieja-szlachcica z dawnego Phalormu, starożytnego królestwa, które niegdyś kontrolowało większą część Północy, twierdza składa się z siedmiu nakładających się na siebie wież, jednak jej górne poziomy już dawno zawaliły się na sterty rozpadającego się muru. Jedynie parter jest jeszcze na tyle zdrowy, by nadawał się do zamieszkania.

entries.name: General Features
entries: Wieki nie były łaskawe dla zamku Cragmaw. Gobliny podpierają najsłabsze miejsca pod walącymi się wieżami prymitywnymi belkami, ale tylko kwestią czasu jest, kiedy budowla całkowicie się zawali.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: Sufity mają wysokość 15 stóp, chyba że zaznaczono inaczej.

entries.name: Doors
entries: Drzwi wewnętrzne są wykonane z drewna wzmocnionego żelaznymi opaskami. Nie mają zamków ani otworów na klucze. Wyważenie zabarykadowanych drzwi wymaga udanego testu Wytrzymałości DC 15.

entries.name: Floors
entries: Popękane i nierówne płyty chodnikowe skrywają pod sobą brudną podłogę.

entries.name: Light
entries: Przez szczeliny strzałkowe wokół zamku przenika niewielka ilość naturalnego światła. W ciągu dnia w większości miejsc jest ono słabo oświetlone. W nocy wszystkie obszary są ciemne.

entries.name: Walls
entries: Ściany zewnętrzne i nośne ściany wewnętrzne mają grubość 5 stóp, z czego 3 stopy to zaprawione wypełnienie umieszczone pomiędzy blokami z twardego kamienia o grubości 1 stopy. Ściany wewnętrzne są wykonane z kamienia obrabianego o grubości 1 stopy.

Szczeliny na strzały w murach zamku znajdują się 10 stóp nad poziomem terenu na zewnątrz, 4 stopy nad poziomem podłogi wewnątrz, 8 cali szerokości i 4 stopy wysokości. Istota znajdująca się po jednej stronie szczeliny na strzałę zyskuje trzy czwarte osłony przed atakami z drugiej strony (patrz "Osłona" w podręczniku zasad).

entries.name: 1. Castle Entrance
entries: Główne bramy między obszarami 1 i 2 są wykonane z drewna pokrytego brązem, ale są skorodowane i zawalone.

Zamek składa się z siedmiu rozpadających się wież różnej wielkości i wysokości, ale wszystkie górne kondygnacje są w różnym stanie zawalenia. Krótkie schody prowadzą na taras przed głównym wejściem. Za wrakiem pary rozbitych drzwi znajduje się zacieniony hol. Nad wejściem górują okrągłe wieże, a ciemne szczeliny strzałek spoglądają w dół na taras.

Nie mieszkają tu żadne potwory, ale strażnicy goblinów w {@area 3|119} prawdopodobnie pełnią wartę. Spoglądają jednak tylko od czasu do czasu przez szczeliny strzał, więc postacie, które poruszają się cicho, mogą zdołać się obok nich przekraść. Każ każdej postaci wykonać test Zręczności ({@skill Stealth}). Najniższy wynik testu to DC dla testów Mądrości goblinów, które pozwolą im zauważyć grupę.

entries.name: Developments
entries: Jeśli gobliny zauważą bohaterów (lub jeśli bohaterowie podejdą otwarcie), gobliny wystrzeliwują strzały zza szczelin na strzały. Nie mogą one jednak strzelać bezpośrednio do przeciwników znajdujących się przy lub za zniszczoną bramą. Gobliny krzyczą również wystarczająco głośno, aby ostrzec swoich towarzyszy z obszarów 4 i 6, że zamek jest atakowany.
{@b Disguised Characters}

Zamiast szturmować zamek Cragmaw z bronią w ręku, sprytne postacie mogą spróbować przedostać się do środka za pomocą rozmowy. Mogą na przykład przywdziać szkarłatne peleryny Redbrandów i podać się za emisariuszy wysłanych przez Iarna "Glasstaffa" Albreka, przywódcę Redbrandów, na spotkanie z królem Grollem. Dobry DM nagradza tego rodzaju spryt, dając bohaterom szansę na sukces.

Nie ma problemu, jeśli bohaterowie omijają walkę i rozmawiają z obrońcami zamku. Zarówno plemię Cragmaw, jak i Czerwone Marki pracują dla Czarnego Pająka, więc goblinoidy raczej nie zaatakują drużyny, jeśli będą twierdzić, że działają w interesie Czarnego Pająka.

Jeśli postacie próbują dokonać podstępu jako grupa, niech każda z nich wykona test Charyzmy ({@skill Deception}), który jest kwestionowany przez testy Mądrości ({@skill Insight}) potworów, i daj postaciom przewagę w swoich testach, jeśli podstęp jest szczególnie dobrze zaplanowany lub odgrywany. Jeśli przynajmniej jedna z postaci wygra konkurs, podstęp jest udany. W miarę jak grupa będzie się zapuszczać coraz głębiej w zamek, mogą być wymagane dodatkowe sprawdziany, według Twojego uznania.

entries.name: 2. Trapped Hall
entries: Ta szeroka sala, będąca niegdyś zamkowym foyer, stanowi niebezpieczne pole bitwy.

Na północy i południu drzwi są zamknięte, a południową salę częściowo zasłania rozpadający się kopiec gruzu. Na wschodzie szeroki korytarz kończy się dwoma kolejnymi drzwiami prowadzącymi na południe i wschód. Korytarz jest zagracony zakurzonym gruzem i odpadającym tynkiem z częściowego zawalenia się sufitu nad głową.

Jeśli goblińskie posterunki w {@area 3|119} podniosły alarm, gobliny i hobgobliny z obszarów 4 i 6 wybiegają jednocześnie z północnych i południowych drzwi. Atakują z obu kierunków, próbując obezwładnić poszukiwaczy przygód i wypędzić ich z zamku.

entries.name: Trap
entries: Zakurzony tynk i gruz przed drzwiami prowadzącymi do {@area 8|12a} kryje miedzianą linkę połączoną z kołkami ukrytymi w zrujnowanym suficie. Zauważenie linki wymaga pasywnego wyniku testu Mądrości ({@skill Perception}) na poziomie co najmniej 20 lub udanego testu Mądrości DC 10 ({@skill Perception}), jeśli postacie aktywnie szukają pułapek w okolicy. Po zauważeniu, można ją łatwo ominąć i rozbroić (nie jest wymagane sprawdzenie umiejętności).

Każda istota, która przejdzie po gruzach bez ominięcia linki uruchamia zawalanie się drewnianych belek i ciężkich kamieni. (Obszar zawalenia jest zaznaczony na mapie.) Każde stworzenie, które znajdzie się w tym obszarze w momencie uruchomienia pułapki, musi wykonać rzut obronny na zręczność DC 10 albo otrzyma {@damage 3d6} obrażeń od spadających gruzów (połowa obrażeń przy udanym rzucie). Hałas spowodowany zawaleniem się budynku postawił potwory z obszarów 3, 7, 8 i 9 w stan gotowości.

entries.name: Awarding Experience Points
entries: Podziel 100 XP po równo między bohaterów, jeśli partia wykryje lub przeżyje pułapkę.

entries.name: 3. Archer Post
entries: Głównymi atutami zamku Cragmaw są jego sekretne położenie i wrażenie, że został opuszczony. Ponadto król Grol rozstawia wartowników, którzy odstraszają intruzów podchodzących zbyt blisko.
To małe pomieszczenie jest zaśmiecone gruzem. Ze szczeliny strzałkowej naprzeciwko drzwi widać pole ostrzału tarasu przed bramą zamku.

W każdym z tych dwóch pomieszczeń przebywa dwóch {@creature goblin||goblins}. Strzelając na zmianę strzałami i chowając się za siebie, obaj łucznicy mogą w każdej turze strzelać do celów na zewnątrz. Kiedy postacie wchodzą do pomieszczenia, gobliny porzucają swoje krótkie łuki i wyciągają broń do walki wręcz.

entries.name: Awarding Experience Points
entries: Podziel po równo 100 XP pomiędzy bohaterów za każdą parę goblińskich łuczników, których pokona grupa.

entries.name: 4. Ruined Barracks
entries: Gobliny z Cragmaw wykorzystują każdy skrawek wolnej przestrzeni w zamku.
Południowo-zachodnia wieża zamku jest niczym więcej niż stertą gruzu. Na pozostałej powierzchni leży kilka poszarpanych łóżek, a przez ruiny prowadzi na wschód małe, kręte przejście.
Trzy {@creature goblin||goblins} prycze. Choć gruzowisko wydaje się niebezpieczne, wieża jest stabilna, a wschodnie przejście bezpieczne.

entries.name: Developments
entries: Wszelkie głośne dźwięki w tym miejscu przyciągają uwagę goblinów w {@area 7|127}. Jeden goblin przychodzi, aby zbadać sytuację. Jeśli nie wróci, lub jeśli zauważy kłopoty i podniesie alarm, pozostałe gobliny zbadają sprawę.

entries.name: Awarding Experience Points
entries: Podziel 150 XP po równo między bohaterów, jeśli partia pokona te gobliny.

entries.name: 5. Storeroom
entries: Karawany najeżdżane przez Cragmaws wzdłuż High Road i Triboar Trail dostarczają zaopatrzenie dla zamku.
Stare beczki z solonym mięsem i worki z gnijącym zbożem wypełniają ten magazyn. Wśród zapasów widzisz zakrwawioną zbroję z łańcuchów, ciężką kuszę i nienaostrzony miecz z godłem Neverwinter.
Choć tutejsze sklepy nie są jadalne według ludzkich standardów, gobliny tolerują je, gdy nie ma dostępu do świeższego pożywienia.

Jedna mała beczułka wypełniona jest wyjątkową krasnoludzką brandy, którą gobliny przeoczyły ze względu na jej rozmiar. Beczka zawiera równowartość dwudziestu kieliszków. Postać, która wypije szklankę brandy, odzyskuje 1 punkt trafienia, ale postać, która wypije dwie szklanki w ciągu godziny, traci {@condition poisoned} na 1 godzinę.

entries.name: Sildar's Gear
entries: Kolczuga i miecz należą do {@creature Sildar Hallwinter|LMoP}. Sildar będzie wdzięczny, jeśli przynajmniej jego miecz zostanie mu zwrócony.

entries.name: 6. Hobgoblin Barracks
entries: Cragmaws to mieszane plemię goblinoidów, z garstką bugbearów panujących nad większą liczbą nędznych goblinów i kilkoma hobgoblinami. Hobgobliny planują pozbyć się bugbearów i przejąć kiedyś władzę, ale na razie bugbearowie stanowią zbyt duże zagrożenie.

Na podłodze tego baraku leżą cztery zwykłe słomiane palety i koce. W uchwytach na ścianach znajduje się wiele rodzajów broni - włócznie, miecze, poranne drzewce i inne. Na północnej ścianie widać ślady uszkodzeń, ale podłoga jest oczyszczona z gruzu.

W tym pomieszczeniu ćwiartują się cztery {@creature hobgoblin||hobgoblins} osoby. Ponieważ ich sąsiedzi gobliny zawsze wdają się w bójki, nie zwracają uwagi na hałas w obszarach 2 i 3. Są jednak gotowi bronić swojej wieży w razie pojawienia się intruzów lub zareagować na alarm podniesiony przez goblińskie posterunki.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Na ścianach zamocowano pięć włóczni, cztery miecze, trzy gwiazdy poranne, dwa miecze świetlne i świetny miecz. Pałka ma wygrawerowane stylizowane pióra, jest zaskakująco lekka (1 funt) i warta 10 gp.

entries.name: Awarding Experience Points
entries: Podziel 400 XP po równo między bohaterów, jeśli partia pokona hobgobliny w tym pomieszczeniu.

entries.name: 7. Banquet Hall
entries: Niegdyś władca zamku przyjmował tu swoich gości, urządzając wystawne bankiety i tańce. Teraz to miejsce jest obrzydliwą mesą goblinów.

Zachodnia część tej dużej sali kończy się ścianą gruzu, ale pozostała część jest nadal nienaruszona. Musiała to być kiedyś sala bankietowa zamku, ze strzelistym sufitem o wysokości 25 stóp. Na środku pomieszczenia stoją dwa duże drewniane stoły z prostymi ławami, a w jednym z rogów stoi mosiężny piec pełen żarzących się węgli. Na stołach leżą brudne naczynia, do połowy wypełnione garnki, spleśniałe piętki chleba i nadgryzione kości.

W tej sali znajduje się siedmiu nieszczęśników {@creature goblin||goblins} i ich przywódca - gruby, upierdliwy {@creature goblin} z 12 punktami życia o imieniu Jegg. Jegg jest głównym kucharzem Cragmawów i zaciekle znęca się nad swoimi niechętnymi pomocnikami, gdy ci wykonują pracę polegającą na nakładaniu jedzenia na stół plemienia. Jeśli Yegg zostanie zabity, wszystkie pozostałe przy życiu gobliny uciekają na wschód lub zachód, unikając północnych drzwi z powodu pułapki w {@area 2|115}.

entries.name: Awarding Experience Points
entries: Podziel 400 XP po równo między bohaterów, jeśli partia pokona gobliny w tym pomieszczeniu.

entries.name: 8. Dark Hall
entries: Nawet w dzień ten obszar nie ma światła zewnętrznego. W tekście w ramce założono, że postacie mają {@sense darkvision} lub źródło światła.

Ta wysoka, wąska sala wygląda tak, jakby kiedyś mogła być częścią kaplicy lub sanktuarium. W górnej części sali wyrzeźbione są postacie aniołów, które spoglądają na podłogę poniżej. Na północy ciężkie zasłony zasłaniają pasującą parę łuków. Pomiędzy nimi znajduje się pęknięta, ale ozdobnie rzeźbiona kamienna lutnia.

W tej komnacie znajduje się {@creature grick}, specjalne zwierzę domowe goblina Lhupo ({@area 9|12f}). Lhupo lubi wspinać się na półkę ukrytą w cieniu posągów w wyższych partiach pomieszczenia. Po cichu obserwuje intruzów, którzy wchodzą na ten teren, zanim spadnie na dół, by zaatakować. Porównaj wynik testu Zręczności ({@skill Stealth}) grick'a z wynikami testów Mądrości ({@skill Perception}) postaci (lub ich pasywnymi wynikami), aby określić, kto z nich jest zaskoczony. Grick wie, że gobliny nie powinny być jedzone, chyba że Lhupo tak powie. Reszta Cragmawów jest przerażona zwierzęciem Lhupo i spieszy się przez to pomieszczenie, najlepiej dwójkami lub trójkami.

Każdy kleryk, który zbada wystrój kaplicy, może spróbować wykonać test Inteligencji DC 10 ({@skill Religion}), aby zidentyfikować bóstwa, które kiedyś były tu czczone: Oghma (bóg wiedzy), Mystra (bogini magii), Lathander (bóg świtu) i Tymora (bogini szczęścia). Jest to oczywisty znak, że budowniczymi zamku byli ludzie.

entries.name: Developments
entries: Jeśli wybuchnie tu walka, gobliny w {@area 9|12f} nie mogą zostać zaskoczone.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: W kamiennym palenisku znajduje się kopiec węgla, pod którym zakopana jest złota figurka elfa słonecznego (100 gp) owinięta w karmazynowy materiał. Goblin ukrył tu figurkę, mając nadzieję, że inne gobliny mu jej nie ukradną.

Zaklęcie {@spell detect magic} ujawnia, że statuetka jest przesiąknięta magią wróżbiarską. Każda nie-zła istota, która chwyci statuetkę, może zadać jej pytanie i otrzymać telepatyczną odpowiedź, tak jakby rzuciła {@spell augury} (opis tego zaklęcia znajduje się w księdze zasad). Po zadaniu pytania i otrzymaniu odpowiedzi istota nie może już nigdy więcej aktywować statuetki.

entries.name: Awarding Experience Points
entries: Podziel 450 XP po równo między bohaterów, jeśli partia pokona grick'a.

entries.name: 9. Goblin Shrine
entries: Gobliny nie korzystają z ludzkich bogów, więc Cragmawowie poświęcili to miejsce Maglubiyetowi, bogu goblinów i hobgoblinów.

Komnata ta zajmuje północną wieżę zamku. Na środku pomieszczenia stoi kamienny ołtarz, przykryty zakrwawioną czarną tkaniną. Złote przybory rytualne - kielich, nóż i kadzielnica - są starannie ułożone na szczycie ołtarza. Dwa łuki od strony południowej są zasłonięte ciężkimi kotarami.

Ta świątynia jest domem Lhupo {@creature goblin} z 12 punktami życia) i dwóch zwykłych {@creature goblin||goblins}, którzy służą jako jego "akolici". Wszyscy noszą brudne szaty na swoich zbrojach, ale żaden z nich nie posiada boskich mocy (choć Lhupo twierdzi, że słyszy, jak Maglubiyet do niego przemawia). Jeśli gobliny słyszały, jak bohaterowie walczą z grickami w {@area 8|12a}, chowają się za ołtarzem i próbują ich zaskoczyć. W przeciwnym razie, wszystkie trzy gobliny klęczą przed ołtarzem, modląc się do swojego złego boga.
Zakrwawiona tkanina całkowicie pokrywa kamienny ołtarz, na którego bokach wyryte są wizerunki tych samych bogów, których odzwierciedleniem jest wystrój znaleziony w {@area 8|12a}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Kielich, nóż i kadzielnica to przedmioty sztuki wykonane przez człowieka, warte odpowiednio 150 gp, 60 gp i 120 gp.

entries.name: Awarding Experience Points
entries: Podziel 150 XP po równo między bohaterów, jeśli partia pokona gobliny.
To boczne wejście do zamku jest zamknięte, ale niestrzeżone.

Po południowej stronie starego zamku zarośnięta ścieżka prowadzi do przejścia, które wspina się w głąb muru. Stoją tu duże żelazne drzwi, osłonięte przed bezpośrednim atakiem z zewnątrz. Na ścieżkę wychodzą szczeliny strzałowe na wysokości dziesięciu stóp nad ziemią.
Żelazne drzwi są zamknięte. Można je otworzyć za pomocą {@item thieves' tools|PHB} i udanego testu Zręczności DC 15 lub wyważyć za pomocą udanego testu Wytrzymałości DC 25.

entries.name: Arrow Slits
entries: Postać, która zatrzyma się i nasłucha w pobliżu szczelin strzał, usłyszy z {@area 7|127} sporadyczny stukot naczyń i wściekłe gobliny kłócące się o to, czy naczynia wymagają mycia. Z tych szczelin strzałki nie obserwują gobliny. Jeśli jednak bohaterowie zrobią dużo hałasu lub zamieszania, np. wyważą drzwi, gobliny przyjdą i popatrzą. Jeśli zobaczą intruzów na zewnątrz, krzyczą na alarm.

entries.name: 11. Ruined Tower
entries: Zakurzone płótno (oznaczone literą "C" na mapie) skrywa północne wejście do tego obszaru, wtapiając się w otaczające je kamienne budowle i gruzowiska. Postać, której powiedzie się test Mądrości DC 15 ({@skill Perception}), dostrzeże ścieżkę prowadzącą do ukrytego wejścia. Jeśli bohaterowie aktywnie przeszukują teren zamku w poszukiwaniu ukrytego wejścia, mogą wykonać test Mądrości DC 10 ({@skill Perception}), aby dostrzec płócienne "drzwi".

Ta wieża prawie całkowicie się zawaliła, choć na parterze wciąż jest trochę wolnej przestrzeni. Gnijące skrzynie i starożytne beczki świadczą o tym, że kiedyś przechowywano tu zapasy. Ciężka zasłona blokuje rozpadający się obszar na południu, a nienaruszone drzwi prowadzą na wschód. Na północy krótkie przejście przez gruzy kończy się przed zasłoną z płótna.

entries.name: 12. Guard Barracks
entries: Tutejsze stwory obserwują okolicę ze szczeliny strzałkowej, więc każda postać skradająca się po wschodniej stronie zamku może zostać zauważona i zaatakowana.

Na środku tego małego baraku żarzy się kamienny piec pełen węgli. Wzdłuż wschodniej ściany ustawione są cztery palety słomy. Ściana na południu jest zawalona, ale zakratowane drewniane drzwi w tamtym kierunku są nadal widoczne. W łuku na północy wisi zasłona.

W tym pomieszczeniu stoi dwóch {@creature hobgoblin||hobgoblins} strażników. Są sprytne, wytrzymałe i lojalne wobec króla Grola. Na początku walki jeden hobgoblin biegnie, aby ostrzec króla w {@area 14|140}, a następnie wraca po 2 turach, aby ponownie dołączyć do walki.
W tym miejscu znajdował się niegdyś salon ludzkich mieszkańców zamku, ale jego spróchniałe wyposażenie zostało zniszczone przez Cragmawów i wykorzystane na opał.

entries.name: Awarding Experience Points
entries: Podziel 200 XP po równo między bohaterów, jeśli partia pokona hobgobliny.

entries.name: 13. Owlbear Tower
entries: Drzwi do tego pokoju są zamknięte ciężką drewnianą kratą - to subtelne ostrzeżenie, że za nimi czai się niebezpieczeństwo. Po podniesieniu belki istota znajdująca się w pokoju budzi się i wydaje z siebie straszliwy ryk.
Szczeliny strzałek są zasłonięte, co sprawia, że w pomieszczeniu jest ciemno. W tekście w ramce założono, że postacie mają {@sense darkvision} lub źródło światła.

Górne piętra wieży zawaliły się, tworząc pusty silos o wysokości co najmniej 30 stóp, a górne partie pomieszczenia pogrążone są w cieniu. Kurz, gruz i potłuczone szkło pokrywają podłogę, a stare stoły robocze i półki z książkami leżą porozrzucane na południe. Na środku pokoju stoi potężna bestia, przypominająca parszywego niedźwiedzia z głową sowy. Gdy Cię zobaczy, podnosi się i ryczy.

The Cragmaws have captured an {@creature owlbear} and confined it to this tower. The room is kept dark to keep the beast calm, but King Grol doesn't know what to do with it yet. If a character throws it fresh meat, the owlbear devours the food. Otherwise, it attacks the first creature it sees in the doorway.
This room was once a library and workshop, but nothing of its original contents remains intact.

entries.name: Developments
entries: If the characters open the door and stay out of the owlbear's way, it flees the castle (most likely through {@area 11|136}). The creature attacks anything that gets in its way.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: All that remains of the tower's second floor is a jagged ledge, upon which sits a battered wooden chest. The chest is hard to see from the floor, requiring a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check to notice. The chest is unlocked and contains 90 ep, 120 gp, a {@item potion of healing}, a {@item Spell Scroll (2nd level)||scroll of} {@spell silence}, and a {@item Spell Scroll (3rd level)||scroll of} {@spell revivify}.

entries.name: Awarding Experience Points
entries: Divide 700 XP equally among the characters if the party defeats the owlbear or releases it.

entries.name: 14. King's Quarters
entries: Any character who listens at the door hears two voices in a heated discussion—a loud, growling voice demanding payment for something, and a silky smooth reply.

This chamber has been set up as a crude living space, with thick furs thrown on the floor to serve as carpets, old trophies hanging on the walls, a large bed to the north, and a brazier of coals burning brightly. A round table with several chairs stands to the south near the door. Near the table, on the floor, is an {@condition unconscious} dwarf who looks badly beaten.

King Grol is a fierce old {@creature bugbear} with 45 hit points. He rules the Cragmaws through pure intimidation. Age has stooped his shoulders and hunched his back, but he remains surprisingly agile and strong. He is demanding and vindictive, and no Cragmaw dares to cross him.

Grol is attended by Snarl, a {@creature wolf} with 18 hit points, and a {@creature doppelganger} disguised as a female drow. The doppelganger, Vyerith, is a messenger from the Black Spider, come to collect {@creature Gundren Rockseeker|LMoP} and the map of Wave Echo Cave from King Grol. Grol wants to sell the map instead of surrendering it. and he and the drow are negotiating a price. Vyerith first wants to question Gundren to find out if anyone else knows the location of the mine. Then the doppelganger intends to kill the dwarf and destroy the map.

If the villains have been warned that an attack is imminent, Vyerith hides behind the door to the northeast, leaving it open a crack and hoping to attack an intruder from the rear. Grol holds Gundren hostage, ready to kill the dwarf if the characters don't back off.

entries.name: Arrow Slits
entries: The arrow slits are 15 feet above the ground outside, and the creatures here aren't keeping watch. They are unlikely to notice intruders moving around the exterior of the castle.

entries.name: Northwest Room
entries: This partially collapsed chamber was once a comfortable bathroom. It still contains a large tile tub, unused by the castle's current occupants.

entries.name: Unconscious Dwarf
entries: Near the southwest corner of the room is {@creature Gundren Rockseeker|LMoP}, a dwarf {@creature commoner}. He is {@condition unconscious} but stable at 0 hit points.

entries.name: Developments
entries: If Grol is killed, Vyerith tries to kill Gundren and flee with the map, heading toward {@area 11|136} and escaping through the concealed canvas door. If cornered, the doppelganger fights to the death rather than allow itself to be captured.

If Gundren is revived, he thanks the party for coming to his rescue but won't leave Cragmaw Castle without his map. Unfortunately, he doesn't know where King Grol has hidden it (see the "Treasure" section).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Hidden under Grol's bed mattress is a stitched leather sack containing 220 sp, 160 ep, three {@item potion of healing||potions of healing}, and Gundren's map to Wave Echo Cave.

entries.name: Awarding Experience Points
entries: Divide 950 XP equally among the characters if the party defeats King Grol, the wolf, and the doppelganger.
Award an additional 200 XP to the party if the characters rescue {@creature Gundren Rockseeker|LMoP} and escort him safely back to Phandalin.

entries.name: Returning War Band
entries: You can add a complication in the form of a hobgoblin war band returning home, just as the characters are preparing to leave. This war band consists of three {@creature hobgoblin||hobgoblins} led by Targor Bloodsword, a {@creature hobgoblin} with 20 hit points. Targor also has two {@creature wolf||wolves} as pets.

The hobgoblins have no treasure, but {@dice 1d4} of them carry bloody sacks, each containing a severed elf head. The severed heads are trophies from the hobgoblins' recent victory over an elf hunting party.

Clever characters might try to reason with Targor by urging him to think of himself as Grol's successor rather than Grol's avenger. Targor has long aspired to lead the Cragmaw tribe, so he might do the adventurers the favor of not killing them, provided one or more characters succeed on a DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check.

entries.name: Awarding Experience Points
entries: Divide 500 XP equally among the characters if they defeat the hobgoblin war band or come to terms with Targor.

entries.name: What's Next?
entries: If {@creature Gundren Rockseeker|LMoP} survives the ordeal at Cragmaw Castle, he offers the characters his thanks and asks that they escort him back to Phandalin and then venture to Wave Echo Cave to learn the fate of his brothers, Nundro and Tharden. He knows that someone called the Black Spider orchestrated his capture and hopes that the characters stop the villain. Upon returning to Phandalin, Gundren offers the characters 25 gp each for their assistance and promises the party a 10 percent share of the mine's wealth once his operation there is up and running.

Whether the characters sought the information from Agatha or Reidoth, negotiated with Hamun Kost, or recovered Gundren and his map from Cragmaw Castle, they now know the location of Wave Echo Cave. The only thing left for them to do is seek out the old dwarven delve and discover for themselves who the Black Spider is, and why he's so interested in the Lost Mine of Phandelver.

data.name: Wave Echo Cave
entries: Fifteen miles east of Phandalin, in the deep vales of the Sword Mountains, lies Wave Echo Cave. The rich mine of the Phandelver's Pact was lost five hundred years ago during orc invasions that devastated this part of the North.

In the centuries since, countless prospectors and adventurers have searched for the lost mine, but none succeeded until the Rockseeker brothers found the entrance a month ago. Unfortunately, the Rockseekers did not realize they were being trailed by spies working for Nezznar, the Black Spider, and they inadvertently led the drow villain to their prize. Nezznar and his followers dealt with the two Rockseekers who were guarding their find, then arranged for Gundren's ambush. Learning of the adventurers' involvement with Gundren or their exploits in and around Phandalin, the Black Spider has given orders for the characters to be dealt with. Meanwhile, Nezznar has begun his exploration of Wave Echo Cave.

The drow is searching for the Forge of Spells, where the human mages of old Phandalin enchanted dwarven weapons and gnome gadgets. However, Nezznar's exploration has been hindered by the restless undead and dangerous monsters that lurk in Wave Echo Cave, forcing him to proceed with great caution.

The adventurers now have the chance to aid Gundren, avenge his kin, and put a stop to the nefarious schemes of the Black Spider. And of course, the hoard of powerful magic rumored to be hidden in the mines is a rich prize.

entries.name: Character Level
entries: This part of the adventure is designed for characters of at least 4th level and assumes that each character has earned at least 2,700 XP. If the adventurers skipped too many of the optional investigations and encounters in part 3, they might not be 4th level, and many of the encounters in this section might be difficult for them.

entries.name: Experience Point Awards
entries: In this part of the adventure, XP is awarded for overcoming monsters, as in parts 2 and 3. However, XP awards for monsters is not given in the encounter description. Instead, the amount of XP that a monster is worth is noted in us stat block. You calculate the award by totaling the value for each monster the characters overcome. Additional XP awards, and the reasons for them, are described in the text, under the "Awarding Experience Points" heading.

entries.name: Wandering Monsters
entries: Monsters roam through all areas of the mine. Random encounters remind players that monsters aren't necessarily confined to specific areas, and that no part of the dungeon is safe. Encounters with wandering monsters are an effective way to keep the players and characters on their toes, alleviate player boredom, and tax party resources. However, having too many random encounters can become tedious, so use them sparingly.

If the characters spend a long time in a given area, you can check for wandering monsters by rolling a {@dice d20}. On a roll of 17-20, an encounter takes place. Conversely, if the players seem restless, you can decide that an encounter occurs. Roll a {@dice d12} and consult the Wandering Monsters table to determine what the party meets.

entries.name: General Features
entries: The mine is cold, damp, and surprisingly drafty. A noticeable breeze blows through many of its passages, flowing from {@area 1|158} toward {@area 16|182}.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: Tunnels are 10 feet high unless noted otherwise. Rooms have 20-foot-high ceilings, while natural caverns have 30-foot-high ceilings dotted with stalactites.

entries.name: Doors
entries: Unless noted otherwise, all doors are 6 feet tall, 4 feet wide, and made of six-inch-thick cut slabs of stone fitted with iron handles and hinges. The doors are low and wide-perfect for dwarves.

entries.name: Walls
entries: The walls are hewn stone. In a few areas (14, 15, 19, and 20), they are dressed with well-fitted stone blocks.

entries.name: Floors
entries: All floors are smooth, natural stone.

entries.name: Light
entries: None unless otherwise indicated. The boxed text assumes that the characters have light sources or {@sense darkvision}.

entries.name: Stalagmites
entries: Found in many of the natural caverns, these spires of rock rise up from the floor and can be used for cover (see "Cover" in the rulebook).

entries.name: Keyed Encounters
entries: All the encounters in this part of the adventure are keyed to the map of Wave Echo Cave.

entries.name: Booming Waves
entries: All good dungeons have characteristics that make them unique, and Wave Echo Cave is no exception. The rhythmic thunder of pounding waves echoes throughout the mine, loud enough to make the stone underfoot shiver. Waves come about two minutes apart, growing louder toward the northeast.

Wave Echo Cave is nowhere near the ocean, but a water-filled cavern deep in the mine is connected to an underground hot spring. That spring boils over continuously to produce a surge that slams into a narrow funnel, making a sound like breaking surf. Describe this sound to players on occasion. It will pique their curiosity and lure them toward its source, drawing them deeper into the mine as a consequence.

entries.name: 1. Cave Entrance
entries: Whether the characters follow Gundren's map or receive directions to Wave Echo Cave from another source, their initial approach leads them to a narrow tunnel whose entrance is hidden within the Sword Mountain foothills.

The entrance tunnel leads into a large cavern supported by a natural pillar of rock and containing three stalagmites. In the western part of the cave, behind the column of rock, are three bedrolls and a heap of ordinary supplies-sacks of flour, bags of salt, casks of salted meat, lanterns, flasks of lamp oil, pickaxes, shovels, and other gear. Amid the supplies, you see the body of a dwarf miner, dead for at least a week.

The northeastern section of the cavern has collapsed, forming a ten-foot-wide, twenty-foot-deep pit. A sturdy hemp rope is tied off around a nearby stalagmite and dangles down the side of the pit, at the bottom of which is a rough-hewn tunnel heading northwest and east.

This was the campsite of the Rockseekers. The dead dwarf is Tharden, Gundren's brother, who was killed by the Black Spider. Gundren's other brother, Nundro, was here as well and is currently the Black Spider's prisoner in {@area 20|194}.
The dwarves' supplies are potentially useful, but not particularly valuable.

entries.name: Open Pit
entries: Climbing up or down the wall of the pit without a rope requires a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. A character who fails the check by 5 or more falls and takes {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage per 10 feet fallen, landing {@condition prone} at the bottom. The tunnel at the bottom of the pit leads northwest toward {@area 2|15c} and east toward {@area 3|15e}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Tharden wears a pair of {@item boots of striding and springing}. In his haste to explore the rest of Wave Echo Cave, Nezznar overlooked them.

entries.name: 2. Mine Tunnels
entries: This maze of passages is an old section of Wave Echo Cave's original mine site.
This area consists of numerous intersecting passages. The ceilings here are only six feet high, and several of the passages end in partially excavated rock faces.

The dead-end passages are places where the miners gave up and decided to move on to other spots. Patiently lurking in one is an {@creature ochre jelly}. When the party enters this section of the mine, the jelly begins to stalk the group, instinctively waiting for an opportunity to attack a lone target.

entries.name: 3. Old Entrance
entries: The tunnel that runs south was the original entrance to Wave Echo Cave, but it was buried by the destruction that wracked the mines centuries ago. A pitched battle was fought here when the orcs stormed the mines. The dead still lie where they fell.

Many tunnels intersect at this natural, thirty-foot-high cavern. The walls are carved with simple reliefs showing dwarf and gnome miners hard at work. Below them, nearly two dozen skeletons in rusted scraps of armor are scattered across the cavern floor. Some are dwarf skeletons, while others are orc remains. Half a dozen large brass lanterns stand in niches or on ledges around the cavern, but none are lit.

Clinging to the ceiling like bats are ten {@creature stirge||stirges}. The monsters find scant living prey in the mines, and they are ravenous. If the characters are looking down at the skeletons on the floor, the stirges are likely get the drop on them. Any character who isn't watching the ceiling is surprised unless his or her passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score is higher than the stirges' Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check total (roll once for all of them). Characters who aren't surprised hear a flapping noise as the stirges descend to attack.
The lanterns and the carvings of miners at work were meant as a welcome to newcomers.

entries.name: 4. Old Guardroom
entries: This guardroom once protected the nearby entrance to the mine, but it was overrun early in the fighting when the orcs attacked.
Splintered stone benches and heaps of rubble from a partially collapsed ceiling fill this room. Amid ruined stone bunks and toppled weapon racks are the bones of several dwarves and orcs.
In the round after any living creature enters this chamber, the bones begin to stir and knit together, forming nine {@creature skeleton||skeletons}. They fight until destroyed.

entries.name: 5. Assayers' Office
entries: The mine's assayers worked here, weighing and assessing ore samples and paying the minors for their labor.

This chamber was once an office or storeroom of some kind. A large stone counter bisects the room, set with three dusty balance scales made of iron. Cubbyholes carved into the north wall are stuffed with dusty paper scraps. Several long-dead corpses-gnomes and orcs by their look-are sprawled across the floor.
The centuries-old paper in the cubbyholes disintegrates if touched, but a character who reads Dwarvish can see faint markings on a few scraps, recording weigh-ins and disbursements.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Behind the counter sits a locked iron strongbox, requiring {@item thieves' tools|PHB} and a successful DC 20 Dexterity check to open. This pay chest was overlooked in the fighting and contains 600 cp, 180 sp, 90 ep, and 60 gp.

entries.name: 6. South Barracks
entries: This was a miners' barracks, where the skilled delvers working in Wave Echo Cave rested between shifts. Any character who listens at the partially open door hears faint crunching and splintering sounds with a successful DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

Old stone bunks in orderly rows line the walls of this chamber, and a corroded iron brazier full of old coals stands near the middle of the room. The bones of a half dozen dwarves and orcs lie strewn about, clad in scraps of armor. Three gray, hunched figures squat among the remains, pawing at the scraps and gnawing on the bones.

Three {@creature ghoul||ghouls} from the pack in {@area 9|16c} are here, cracking and gnawing on the ancient bones of the fallen in the vain hope that some tasty morsel of marrow remains. The ghouls, eager for a fresh meal, attack immediately.

entries.name: 7. Ruined Storeroom
entries: Despite the destruction all around, the northern part of this storage area has survived intact.

The eastern wall of this chamber has collapsed into a mass of rubble. To the north, a door stands ajar, leading to a good-sized storeroom. Dusty kegs are tucked neatly against the walls, all of them cracked and split open from age.
It's not comfortable, but the storeroom is a secure resting place. No monsters come this way. Moreover, the storeroom door is in good shape and can easily be blocked or barred from the inside.
The contents of the kegs have long evaporated.

entries.name: 8. Fungi Cavern
entries: This cave has hindered Nezznar's explorations. The drow suspects that the mine's magic workshops are close by, but he's reluctant to risk dealing with the monsters here.

Dense carpets of weird fungi cover large sections of the floor in this cavern. The growth includes puffballs a foot across, weird shelf fungus growing on stalagmites, and large stalks and caps a good five feet tall. Some of the puffballs glow with an eerie green phosphorescence.
Most of the fungi is harmless, and the green-glowing fungi allow creatures to see the entire cavern without the aid of {@sense darkvision} or a light source.

entries.name: Poison Gas
entries: Whenever a creature attempts to cross the cavern, the carpets of fungi that cover most of the floor release poisonous gas into the air. Each creature in the cavern must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 3d6} poison damage and be {@condition poisoned} for 10 minutes (see the rulebook for more information on the {@condition poisoned} condition). The gas disperses after 1 minute, but until then, any living creature that ends its turn in the cavern must repeat the saving throw.

entries.name: 9. Great Cavern
entries: This cave once served as the banquet room, meeting area, and mead hall for the miners.

Steep escarpments divide this large cavern into three sections-high ledges at either end, and a lower section in the middle. Carved stone stairs climb up to the ledges. Two large tables stand in the middle section, along with a pair of old braziers. A smaller table stands on the eastern ledge. The skeletal remains of dozens of dead warriors-dwarves, gnomes, orcs, and ogres-attest to the fierceness of the fighting that took place here long ago.
Seven {@creature ghoul||ghouls} lurk in the shadows on the western ledge.
They notice any light or noise elsewhere in the cave and quickly bound down to attack. The undead are hungry and fight until destroyed.

The escarpments are 10 feet high and require a successful DC 12 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to climb. A creature that falls or is knocked from the top of a ledge takes {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage and lands {@condition prone}.

entries.name: 10. Dark Pool
entries: Treasure is concealed in this water-filled cave.

A still pool fills much of this cavern. The water is dark, revealing little of what might lie within. The shore of the pool consists of a thin layer of broken shells from strange, pale mussels, and a fishy odor hangs in the air.
A passage leads south from this area, and a set of steps climbs up to the east. A sluggish stream flows out of the cave to the northeast.

The pool is 20 feet deep in the middle. The stream to the northeast is 3 feet deep, and the ceiling of the passage is 2 to 3 feet above the water. Characters can easily wade through the stream to {@area 18|186}.

A character who explores the pool finds an old skeleton lying on the bottom, 10 feet from the shore and under 10 feet of water. These are the remains of a human wizard from old Phandalin who died defending the mines against the orc attackers. Several orc arrows are still lodged in the skeleton's ribcage.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The skeleton wears two platinum rings (75 gp each) and clutches a {@item wand of magic missiles} in its bony fingers.

entries.name: 11. North Barracks
entries: The eastern door is barricaded from inside the room and requires a successful DC 20 Strength check to force open. A character who listens at either door and succeeds on a DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check hears gruff voices speaking Goblin and talking about how hungry they are.
Old stone bunks line the walls of this barracks, which is lit and heated by a glowing iron brazier in the middle of the room.
If the party enters from the west, add:
Across the room is another door, this one blocked by a barricade made from the remains of a wooden table.

Five {@creature bugbear||bugbears} reside in this chamber. They are loyal minions of Nezznar. This room marks the front line in the Black Spider's assault on Wave Echo Cave, and the bugbears are here to prevent ghouls, zombies, or other undead from troubling their master in his lair ({@area 19|18b}).
Like {@area 6|165}, this was formerly a barracks for miners. Nezznar's bugbears removed the corpses they found here and built the barricade.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The largest bugbear carries a pouch containing 15 cp. 13ep, and a {@item potion of vitality}.

entries.name: 12. Smelter Cavern
entries: Like the fungi cavern at {@area 8|169}, this chamber poses a serious obstacle that prevents Nezznar from reaching his objective-the Forge of Spells ({@area 15|17d}). The drow is still formulating a plan to get past the undead guardians in this area.

A blast furnace and a mechanical bellows powered by a waterwheel dominate this large chamber. The furnace is cold and dark, but heaps of coal are piled nearby, along with carts full of unrefined ore. The waterwheel sits in a ten-foot-wide channel cut into the floor of the room, but the channel is dry. Passages exit to the west, south, and east. The empty channel exits to the north and east.
More than a dozen withered corpses are scattered around the room. These slain dwarves and orcs are still wearing the remnants of their armor. Floating above them is a skull engulfed in green flame.

Eight of the fallen dwarf warriors are {@creature zombie||zombies}. They rise and pursue any living creatures that enter the room, but they do not pursue creatures outside this area for more than 1 round. In addition, a far more intelligent undead guards this area: a {@creature flameskull}. This creature was a servant of the human wizards allied with the Phandelver dwarves and gnomes, and it continues to act on ancient instructions to prevent intruders from passing through.

This impressive chamber was the heart of the Wave Echo Cave mining operation. Here, the dwarves melted down their ore to refine ingots of silver, gold, and platinum. The dry channel is where the dwarves diverted the stream from {@area 18|186} to power the waterwheel here. That in turn operated the bellows that fed the furnace.

The channel's bottom is 5 feet below floor level, and no ability check is required to scramble in or out. Characters in the channel can follow it out of this room to the north or to the east, though the ceiling is only 5 feet high after the channel exits this room.

entries.name: 13. Starry Cavern
entries: The structural damage and the skeletal remains in this area are evidence of the destructive spell battle fought here centuries ago when the arcs and their mercenary wizards stormed the mines.

Glittering minerals in the ceiling of this large cavern catch the light and send it back to create the impression of a starry night sky. Dozens of skeletons-many crushed under fallen debris-are scattered across the floor.

The cave is large enough that it contains two freestanding structures. Each of these stone buildings is proportioned for human use, as opposed to the dwarf-sized doorways and furnishings you've seen elsewhere in the mines. Both structures have battered and blackened masonry walls, their double doors cracked and scorched. The cavern is divided by an escarpment, into which a flight of stairs has been cut.
Passages lead out of this area to the north, south, and west.
The damaged buildings are described in areas 14 and 15. Minerals in the ceiling are pretty, but they are neither magical nor valuable.

Any character proficient in {@skill Arcana} can sense a subtle aura of magic in this cavern. (A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals the same.) The aura becomes stronger as one approaches the northern building ({@area 15|17d}).

entries.name: 14. Wizards' Quarters
entries: The doors leading into this area are cracked, their iron hinges partially melted. Wrenching or smashing open the doors requires a successful DC 15 Strength check.

Dust, ash, walls blackened by fire, and heaps of debris beneath the sagging ceiling show that this room was damaged by a destructive blast. The furnishings-tables, chairs, bookshelves, beds-are charred or splintered, but otherwise well preserved. A scorched iron chest stands near the foot of one of the beds.

This room contains the restless spirit of the last wizard to die here: {@creature Mormesk the wraith|LMoP}. He is not immediately visible but rises up out of the floor when a living creature enters the room.

Mormesk was a powerful mage until he met his end in the spell battle at the climax of the orc attack. Centuries of anger have {@condition poisoned} his soul, transforming him into a hate-filled apparition.

Mormesk leads the undead that haunt Wave Echo Cave. The wraith spends his time here because the treasure he had amassed in life is in the scorched chest (see the "Treasure" section). No longer corporeal, he cannot touch or possess the wealth he enjoyed in life.
This building served as a guesthouse for visiting wizards working in the Forge of Spells ({@area 15|17d}), most of whom were humans from nearby cities. The furnishings are all human proportioned.

entries.name: Roleplaying Mormesk
entries: Mormesk speaks in grave whispers. When the wraith first rises up from the floor, it says, "Your presence is offensive to me, your life forfeit. My treasures are mine alone, not yours to plunder!" If the characters make no attempt to reason with the wraith, it attacks.

If the characters try to reason with the wraith, it listens to what they have to say, provided they have not harmed it in any way or seized any of its property. The wraith is irrevocably evil, so the only way the characters can stay its spectral hand is to offer it something a former wizard would consider valuable in exchange for their lives. Mormesk values magic items (particularly scrolls), spellbooks, and arcane knowledge. Whatever the gift, a character must succeed on a DC 10 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check to convince the wraith of its value.

Regardless of what the characters offer it, the wraith won't relinquish the wooden pipe in the scorched chest. It will, however, part with the coins and gems if the characters agree to kill the spectator in the Forge of Spells. (The wraith doesn't explain what a spectator is. It merely points toward {@area 15|17d}.) Once it receives its gift, the wraith allows characters to peruse its books and keep the secret map in one of them (see the "Treasure" section).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The scorched chest is unlocked and contains 1,100 cp, 160 sp, 50 ep, three diamonds (100 gp each), and a wooden pipe adorned with platinum filigree (150 gp).

A handful of magically preserved tomes remain on the shelves. Most are just histories, but one has a map sewn into its cover. The map's presence can be discerned with a successful DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. The map shows the location of a dungeon of your own creation. When the characters finish their explorations here, this old map can lead them to their next adventure.

entries.name: 15. Forge of Spells
entries: Here is where the wizards allied with the dwarves and gnomes of the Phandelver's Pact channeled the magic of these caverns to enchant dwarven arms and gnome gadgets. The northernmost door is scorched and cracked, its iron hinges partially melted; forcing it open requires a successful DC 15 Strength check. The western double doors are just as damaged but stand slightly ajar.

This large workshop was badly damaged by the ancient spell battle that laid waste to the mine. Worktables taking up two corners of the room are scorched, and the plaster has been burned off the masonry walls. In the middle of the room, a stone pedestal holds a small brazier in which an eerie green flame dances and crackles. The brazier and its pedestal appear to have been untouched by the forces that destroyed this area.

Behind the brazier of green flame floats a spherical creature measuring roughly four feet in diameter. Four eyestalks protrude from its central mass, two on each side. In the center of the body is a large eye that stares at you. "Hello," says a thick, burbling voice inside your head.

The monster that guards this room is a {@creature spectator}. One of the human wizards who worked in the Forge of Spells summoned the creature to guard the magic items created and stored here. When the mine was sacked, the orcs disturbed the delicate magic in the area, unhinging the spectator's grip on reality. It has become deranged and believes that the mine is still in use, ignoring all evidence to the contrary.

The wraith ({@area 14|179}) wants to drive off or kill the spectator, but so far, the creature has easily handled the assaults of Mormesk's zombies and ghouls while seeing nothing strange about undead roaming the mine. If the party attempts to remove anything from this area, the spectator attacks. If the spectator is {@condition blinded} somehow, it disappears back to its home plane, convinced that it can no longer perform the task for which it was summoned.

With a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check, a character can trick the spectator into thinking one or more party members are wizards or miners who work for the owners of Wave Echo Cave, sent to terminate the spectator's employment. If the deception succeeds, the spectator believes it is released from its obligations, and it disappears and returns to its home plane.

entries.name: Brazier of Green Flame
entries: A successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check identifies the brazier as the source of the magic that suffuses the surrounding caverns. This magic has waned over the years, to the extent that it can no longer be harnessed to permanently enchant magic items. However, any nonmagical weapon or armor bathed in the green flame for at least 1 minute becomes a {@item +1 weapon} or {@item +1 armor}, respectively, for {@dice 1d12} hours. The brazier cannot be removed from the Forge of Spells.

entries.name: Northern Room
entries: This small room is a separate workspace, where items being prepared for enchantment were polished, lacquered, and otherwise finished. Like the main workshop, it has been almost completely destroyed.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: On the worktable in the southeast corner of the room are the last items the spectator was charged to protect: {@item Lightbringer|LMoP} and {@item Dragonguard|LMoP}.

entries.name: 16. Booming Cavern
entries: The sound of pounding surf that gives Wave Echo Cave its name can be traced to this water-filled cavern.

A narrow ledge overlooks a large cavern that houses a surging, seething body of water. The rhythmic booming heard throughout the mines is louder here. At regular intervals, a fresh surge of water funnels into this chamber and slams against the wall just below the ledge. The echo suggests that this cave might be one arm of a much larger cavern to the northeast.

The ledge that hugs the south wall is 15 feet above water level. However, when water surges into the cave every 2 minutes, it raises the water level by 10 feet. After a minute, the water level returns to its normal depth of 20 feet.

entries.name: 17. Old Streambed
entries: The stream flowing from {@area 10|16e} to {@area 18|186} used to continue through this low passage, eventually emptying out into {@area 16|182}.
This passageway is barely four feet high and is obstructed by rounded boulders and pebbles. It might have been a streambed, though no water flows here now.

The dwarves diverted the stream into the channel leading to {@area 12|175} to drive the waterwheel in the smelter. Then the earthquakes that rocked Wave Echo Cave during the final spell battle of the orc invasion collapsed the floor in {@area 18|186}, diverting the stream once again. The old streambed remains as a usable passage that circumvents the undead in {@area 12|175}, although Nezznar has not yet discovered this.

entries.name: 18. Collapsed Cavern
entries: Nezznar's servants occupy this cavern, guarding against undead incursions and carefully sifting through the rubble. The Black Spider's divinations suggest that some valuable treasure is hidden at the bottom of the rift that was created when this area was destroyed.

A wide rift fills the eastern half of this cavern. A stream pours out of the west wall, then tumbles down into the rift and flows out again to the north. Several ropes are secured to iron stakes along on the western edge of the rift, leading down to the chasm floor.

Three {@creature bugbear||bugbears} are stationed here. Two of them are clearing rock on the rift floor while one more stands guard in the western half of the cavern. A {@creature doppelganger} named Vhalak supervises the operation in the guise of a male drow. If a fight breaks out in the main cavern, the two bugbears in the rift climb up the ropes to join the fray.

entries.name: Rift
entries: The rift is 20 feet deep. Climbing up or down without using a rope requires a successful DC 10 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. A creature that fails the check by 5 or more falls and takes {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage per 10 feet fallen, landing {@condition prone} at the bottom.

entries.name: Developments
entries: If two or more bugbears are killed, the doppelganger tries to retreat to {@area 19|18b} to warn Nezznar.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Nezznar's divinations are accurate. Buried under heavy rubble at the bottom of the rift is the crushed skeleton of a dwarf wearing {@item gauntlets of ogre power}. The remains are hidden from view but can be found with a successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. Each character searching can attempt one check per hour.

entries.name: 19. Temple of Dumathoin
entries: Nezznar uses this room as his headquarters while he explores the mines and searches for the Forge of Spells.

Six cracked marble pillars line the walls of this hall, at the north end of which stands a nine-foot-tall statue of a dwarf seated on a throne, a mighty stone warhammer across his lap. Large emeralds gleam in the statue's eyes.

The dust and debris covering the floor has been swept to one side, and a campsite of sorts now spreads in front of the statue. Half a dozen bedrolls and packs are neatly arranged around a rough-built fire pit. A wooden table stands on the west side of the room between two pillars.
If the room's occupants are not aware of the characters as they enter, add the following:

Two bugbears stand by the table, flanking a dark elf dressed in black leather armor and robes. He clutches a black staff with a carved spider at the top and frowns as he sees you. "It seems that I must deal with you myself. A pity it must end this way."

{@creature Nezznar the Black Spider|LMoP} is joined by four {@creature giant spider||giant spiders} that defend their master to the death. If they are expecting trouble, the spiders hide behind pillars, and Nezznar casts {@spell invisibility} on himself and stands near the table. Make a Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check for the spiders. When intruders appear, the spiders try to entangle them in webs before closing to melee range. Nezznar joins the fray on the round after the spiders attack.

If the {@creature doppelganger} from {@area 18|186} retreated to this area, it assumes the guise of {@creature Nundro Rockseeker|LMoP} so that Nezznar can use the "dwarf" as leverage to force the party's surrender (although the drow won't actually harm the doppelganger). See the "Roleplaying Nezznar" section for more information on the drow villain.

entries.name: Statue
entries: The statue depicts Dumathoin, the dwarven god of mining. Any character who has proficiency in {@skill Religion} recognizes the deity. The statue is beautifully carved, and its emerald eyes appear extremely valuable. However, the jewels are clever fakes made of worthless glass, as close inspection and a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check reveals. Nevertheless, a powerful spell protects them, and a {@spell detect magic} spell reveals a strong aura of abjuration magic surrounding the statue.

A character can climb the statue easily and pry a jewel loose with a successful DC 10 Strength check. However, if either eye is removed, the pillars that line the walls crack, triggering a ceiling collapse. Each creature in the room must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 4d10} bludgeoning damage from falling rubble and falling {@condition prone} on a failure, or taking only half the damage on a success.

entries.name: Table
entries: The table is strewn with notes and maps showing Nezznar's efforts at exploring the mine so far. A black leather sack of treasure is amid the papers (see the "Treasure" section).

entries.name: Roleplaying Nezznar
entries: Even though he intends to kill the characters, Nezznar is curious about them. Given the chance, he quizzes the characters at length regarding their identities, allegiances, interests, and goals. He files it all away in memory in the hope that someday he might find a use for what he learns.

Nezznar admits to being the Black Spider, and to using the Cragmaw goblins and the Redbrands to ensure that Wave Echo Cave remains his secret. He will say or do anything to put the characters off their guard, including promising to surrender or proposing cooperation against the monsters impeding his progress toward reaching the Forge of Spells. However, he betrays the characters as soon as they outlive their usefulness.

entries.name: Developments
entries: The creatures in {@area 18|186} can hear sounds of combat in this room. If they haven't already been dealt with, they arrive after 3 rounds and act immediately after Nezznar's giant spiders in the initiative count.

If the characters capture Nezznar and deliver him to the townmaster's hall in Phandalin, the drow is locked up until {@creature Sildar Hallwinter|LMoP} or another representative of the Lords' Alliance can escort him to Neverwinter to face justice and interrogation. However, unless the characters post guards outside Nezznar's cell, Halia Thornton (see page 17) breaks him out of jail, smuggles him out of Phandalin, and delivers him into the waiting arms of the Zhentarim. The Zhents want to learn everything the Black Spider knows about Wave Echo Cave. What happens to Nezznar at that point is up to you.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Nezznar carries a {@item potion of healing} and a {@item spider staff|LMoP}. In addition, the drow carries an iron key with a head shaped like an anvil. This key unlocks the door to {@area 20|194}.

Nezznar's exploration of Wave Echo Cave has yielded some treasure, which the drow keeps in the sack on the wooden table. The sack contains 190 ep, 130 gp, 15 pp, nine small gemstones (10 gp each), and a dwarven ale mug made of hammered electrum (100 gp).

entries.name: Awarding Experience Points
entries: If Nezznar is captured alive and delivered to {@creature Sildar Hallwinter|LMoP} or Townmaster Wester in Phandalin, award the party double his XP value.

entries.name: 20. Priests' Quarters
entries: The door to this room is locked, requiring {@item thieves' tools|PHB} and a successful DC 15 Dexterity check to open. Nezznar ({@area 19|18b}) carries the key.
Unless the characters are being stealthy, any activity at the door attracts the attention of Nezznar and his allies in {@area 19|18b}, prompting the drow to send his giant spiders to investigate.
Dusty draperies adorn the walls of this room, which also contains a bed and brazier. A badly disheveled dwarf lies bound and {@condition unconscious} on the cold stone floor.

This room formerly belonged to the priest in charge of Dumathoin's temple ({@area 19|18b}), but Nezznar has appropriated it for use as a cell. The figure lying on the floor is {@creature Nundro Rockseeker|lmop|Nundro}, a dwarf {@creature commoner} and the youngest of the three Rockseeker brothers. Nezznar spared him because he thought the dwarf might know more about the mine than he admitted. The drow has interrogated Nundro harshly once or twice a day ever since capturing him.

entries.name: Developments
entries: Nundro is grateful if the adventurers rescue him, and he offers to tag along for the duration of their stay in Wave Echo Cave. Nundro doesn't know any more about the layout than the characters, so he hasn't much to offer in the way of useful information. See the "NPC Party Members" sidebar (page 11) for tips on running Nundro.
If the characters deal with Nezznar and his minions, this area serves as a safe and comfortable place to rest before continuing their explorations of the mine.

entries.name: Awarding Experience Points
entries: If Nundro is rescued and survives the adventure, divide 200 XP equally among the characters in the party.

entries.name: Conclusion
entries: With hard work and a little luck, the adventurers have defeated the Black Spider and undone his destructive plots, cleared Phandalin of the ruffians who threatened its people, and reclaimed the lost mine of Wave Echo Cave. Their deeds will be long remembered in this corner of the Sword Coast. In years to come, the restored mines of the Phandelver's Pact will bring great riches to Phandalin and help establish peace and prosperity in the area.

Gundren and {@creature Nundro Rockseeker|LMoP} take over administration of the new mine. For the adventurers' service to their family, they gladly award the party a 10 percent share of the mine's profits. If the characters want to remain in Phandalin and perhaps restore Tresendar Manor or establish homes of their own, the people of the area are glad to have them stay. Even if they choose to move on in search of new adventures, they'll always have a warm welcome in Phandalin.

By the end of the adventure, the characters should be 5th level. If your players wish to continue playing their characters, you can use the contents of this set to create your own adventures; the mysterious map found in {@area 14|179} of Wave Echo Cave provides one possible adventure hook, but feel free to explore other ideas using the monsters, magic items, and locations in this adventure. If you want to create adventures for characters higher than 5th level, you'll need the basic rules online or the advanced rulebooks: the {@i Player's Handbook, Dungeon Master's Guide} and {@i Monster Manual}.

data.name: Appendix A: Magic Items
entries: A magic item is a wondrous treasure that adventurers find in a monster's hoard, in a trap-riddled dungeon, or in the possession of a slain foe. Every adventure holds the promise—but not a guarantee—of finding one or more magic items, and part of the fun of exploring a dungeon is the thrill of unearthing an item found nowhere else.

entries.name: Using a Magic Item
entries: A magic item's description explains how the item works. Handling a magic item is enough to give a character a sense that something is extraordinary about the item. Casting the {@spell identify} spell on the item then reveals its properties. Alternatively, a character can concentrate on the item during a short rest, while being in physical contact with the item. At the end of the rest, the character learns the item's properties. Potions are an exception; a little taste is enough to tell the taster what the potion does.

Certain magic items require a user to {@b attune} to them before their magical properties can be used. Attuning to a magic item requires that you spend a short rest concentrating on it (this can't be the same short rest used to learn an item's properties). Depending on the nature of the item, this concentration can take the form of prayers, weapon practice, or meditation. In any case, the concentration period must be uninterrupted. Once you are attuned to an item, you can use its magical properties.
An item can be attuned to only one creature at a time. A creature can be attuned to no more than three magic items at any given time, and you can attune yourself to only one item during a short rest.
Your attunement to an item ends when the item has been more than 100 feet away from you for 24 hours and when you die. You can also voluntarily end your attunement to an item with another short rest.
